enb_long_title: Eighth Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change
sentences: COP-6 and the resumed thirteenth sessions of the UNFCCC's subsidiary bodies were held in The Hague, the Netherlands, from 13-25 November 2000.
Political positions on the key issues remained entrenched, with little indication of willingness to compromise.

During the second week of negotiations, COP-6 President Jan Pronk (the Netherlands) attempted to facilitate negotiations on the many disputed political and technical issues by convening high-level informal plenary sessions.

He grouped the issues into four 'clusters' or 'boxes': (a) capacity building, technology transfer, adverse effects and guidance to the financial mechanism; (b) mechanisms; (c) LULUCF; and, (d) compliance, P&Ms, and accounting, reporting and review under Protocol Articles 5 ,7 and 8.

After almost 36 hours of intense talks in the final two days, negotiators could not achieve an agreement, with financial issues, supplementarity in the use of the mechanisms, compliance and LULUCF proving particularly difficult.
On Saturday afternoon, 25 November, President Pronk announced that delegates had failed to reach agreement.
Parties agreed to suspend COP-6, and expressed a willingness to resume in 2001.
